Neuropathy and Walking

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎01-13-2013 08:29 PM

If I have neuropathy and my feet are hurting (just a little), is it ok to walk on a tread mill? Will walking help make them better or worse? I don't want to damage them any more than they are.

Patricia
Type 2 for 20+ years
A1c 5.7
Metformin 500 x2

Re: Neuropathy and Walking

Options
  • Mark as New

‎01-14-2013 12:16 AM

texastrish wrote:

If I have neuropathy and my feet are hurting (just a little), is it ok to walk on a tread mill? Will walking help make them better or worse? I don't want to damage them any more than they are.

Walking should not make them worse, and overall will have the benefit of helping you lower your blood glucose levels.  Lowering those levels in turn can help you reverse the neuropathy.

 

the only danger would be if your neuropathy had progressed to the point of totally numb feet. In that case you could injure your foot--say step on a nail--and not know it--and that is the kind of thing that leads to amputations. 

 

But if your feet are not numb, that is not going to happen--that nail will make you scream in pain. And even if they are numb, exercise can be good, but you would want to visually inspect your feed for any injuries that you could see, even when you don't feel them.

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

Patricia

‎01-14-2013 08:27 AM

I have read up on this issue because I have neuropathy. If the burning intensifies after walking, it does not necessarily mean that walking is bad for your feet.  As your doc about it.

Prediabetic
A1C
03/14 5,4
09/13 4.7
03/13 4.8
08/12 5.0

‎01-14-2013 08:32 AM

I did as much exercise as I could when my feet were burning.  My thoughts were to improve the blood flow to my feet (doctors said it was good to start with), and repair whatever things nature would let us repair.  I've seen huge improvements, but can't tell you which of the items I did (exercise, tight control, ALA, luck) were the main contributor.



You go to school to learn, not for a report card.
You use your meter to learn, not for a report card

Type 1 (LADA).. Novolog/Levemir

Adult onset T1

‎01-14-2013 02:04 PM

texastrish wrote:
sunritef wrote:

I did as much exercise as I could when my feet were burning.  My thoughts were to improve the blood flow to my feet (doctors said it was good to start with), and repair whatever things nature would let us repair.  I've seen huge improvements, but can't tell you which of the items I did (exercise, tight control, ALA, luck) were the main contributor.

I started ALA 3 weeks ago when the symptoms started. I'm walking, and working on tight control.

 

What would an A1c be for tight controll? My last one was 6.1, but I know I need to get that down becuase I was not eating very healthy when I got that.

I have read that the changes that lead to neuropathy start at prediabetic levels, now defined as an A1 pof 5.7 to 6.1. It may be that it is as important to keep in a normal range, 80-120, as much as possible--actually that and the normal A1c should  correlate.

 

Bottom line is that the lower you can get it, the better chance you have of removing any predisposition towards nerve damage. Then keep it down and the coast is clear for nerve repair. The ALA may  help with that....

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

‎01-15-2013 01:27 AM

texastrish wrote:

If I have neuropathy and my feet are hurting (just a little), is it ok to walk on a tread mill? Will walking help make them better or worse? I don't want to damage them any more than they are.

How do your feet feel when you massage them, Trish?  Walking on the treadmill feels like it's massaging my feet, and feels really good.  I wear running shoes with Thorlo cushioned walking socks.

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

my toes tingling was the sign i could no longer ignore....i walk almost daily.....and after i walk ...i shower and inspect said feet....as i get the bg under control and diet....my tingling toes are getting better...its raining here..with flood warnings....i am trying to figure out where i am gonna walk.....today...

‎01-15-2013 02:04 PM

Remember as well tha the A1C is just an average of your BG over the  previous 2 -3 months. You also want to make sure you don't have a a huge spieks in your BG as that also will contribute to neuropathy. I know this sounds crazy but for me wearing support socks helps a lot. I don't know why but they do. Of course I can't say they work for everyone. Also if you are on Metformin then ask to have our Vitamin B levels checked. Metformin does seem to deplete the B12 levels in people that are using it so it is a good idea to have that checked. There can be more than one reason for neuropathy including but not always diabetes.

a Deaf person with Diabetes.
